thread.title_full: Florida, Bahamas on alert as tropical storm Erika batters CaribbeanTravelandtourworld.com

author: travelandtourworld.com
title: Florida, Bahamas on alert as tropical storm Erika batters CaribbeanTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Florida, Bahamas on alert as tropical storm Erika batters Caribbean Published on : Thursday, August 27, 2015
Prior to taking a turn toward the Bahamas and Florida this weekend, Erika will bring torrential rain, flash flooding, mudslides and gusty winds to many of the northern islands of the Caribbean Erika will pass through the Leeward and northern Windward islands on Thursday. During Friday, Erika will travel through the British and United States Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.
Erika remains a tropical storm spinning about 85 miles west of Guadeloupe, as of 8 a.m. EDT Thursday.
Winds will blow at an average speed between 40 and 60 mph (64 to 95 kph), with higher gusts posing the threat of uprooting tress, damaging roofs. A general rainfall of 2-4 inches (50-100 mm) is forecast with locally higher amounts.
Bathers and boaters need to be cautious and avoiding going out to the seas.
Flash flooding and mudslides pose the greatest threat. Flash flooding has occurred on some of the Leeward Islands, on the island of Dominica.
AccuWeather Hurricane Expert Dan Kottlowsk explains that ‘Erika will have to survive strong wind shear and the frictional effects of the mountainous islands of Puerto Rico and Hispaniola.’
Erika’s timing of turn to the northwest and then to the north will determine the extent of impacts in the Bahamas and Florida. If the system survives as far north as Florida, there will be concerns farther north into the Southern states, especially in the Carolinas and perhaps as far west as Louisiana.
There is also the chance the system stalls along the Southeast U.S. coast after negotiating Florida waters.
